posts.title: Trump fires director of U.S. Copyright Office, sources say
top_comments:
"...Perlmutter's firing was "a brazen, unprecedented power grab with no legal basis.... surely no coincidence he acted less than a day after she refused to rubber-stamp Elon Musk's efforts to mine troves of copyrighted works to train AI models," in reference to the report released by the Copyright Office this week.  

Last month, Musk took to his social media platform X to seemingly express support for the abolition of intellectual property laws..."

He sure is firing people left and right. Is there a website that tracks all the government heads that are being fired? I know I posted earlier that he fired the Librarian for Congress Friday. [https://federalnewsnetwork.com/workforce/2025/05/president-donald-trump-fires-librarian-of-congress-carla-hayden/](https://federalnewsnetwork.com/workforce/2025/05/president-donald-trump-fires-librarian-of-congress-carla-hayden/)

Edit: Added another name and more details who has been fired..Earlier Thursday, the [acting administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency](https://apnews.com/article/fema-trump-administrator-replaced-emergency-b9ae5e6a7e1c09e51de99c5148f45eb2) was pushed out one day after he had testified that he did not agree with proposals to dismantle the organization. Trump has suggested that individual states, not FEMA, should take the lead on responding to hurricanes, tornadoes and other crises.

At the Pentagon, more than a half-dozen [top general officers have been fired](https://apnews.com/article/trump-brown-joint-chiefs-of-staff-firing-fa428cc1508a583b3bf5e7a5a58f6acf) since January, including the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. CQ Brown Jr. The only two women serving as four-star officers, as well as a disproportionate number of other senior female officers, have also been fired.

posts.title: 'Children handcuffed and shot' - ex-UK Special Forces break silence on war crime claims
top_comments:
"Former members of UK Special Forces have broken years of silence to give BBC Panorama eyewitness accounts of alleged war crimes committed by colleagues in Iraq and Afghanistan.

Giving their accounts publicly for the first time, the veterans described seeing members of the SAS murder unarmed people in their sleep and execute handcuffed detainees, including children.

"They handcuffed a young boy and shot him," recalled one veteran who served with the SAS in Afghanistan. "He was clearly a child, not even close to fighting age."

Killing of detainees "became routine", the veteran said. "They'd search someone, handcuff them, then shoot them", before cutting off the plastic handcuffs used to restrain people and "planting a pistol" by the body, he said.

...

Knowledge of the alleged crimes was not confined to small teams or individual squadrons, according to the testimony. Within the UK Special Forces command structure, "everyone knew" what was happening, said one veteran.

...

"There was a fake grenade they'd take with them onto target, it couldn't detonate," said a former SAS operator. Another veteran said operators would carry AK-47 rifles which had a folding stock because they were easier to fit into their rucksacks and "easier to bring onto a target and plant by a body".

Officers would then help to falsify post-operational reports in order to avoid scrutiny for the actions of assault teams on the ground, according to the testimony.

...

"If it looked like a shooting could represent a breach of the rules of conflict, you'd get a phone call from the legal adviser or one of the staff officers in HQ. They'd pick you up on it and help you to clarify the language. 'Do you remember someone making a sudden move?' 'Oh yeah, I do now.' That sort of thing. It was built into the way we operated."

The reports were "a fiction", another UKSF veteran said.

An intelligence officer who worked with the SBS described reports which said they had been caught in a firefight, while the photos showed bodies with "multiple clean headshots".

...

The Afghan president was "so consistent with his complaints about night raids, civilian casualties and detentions that there was no senior Western diplomat or military leader who would have missed the fact that this was a major irritant for him," said Gen Douglas Lute, a former US ambassador to Nato.

..."

We are outraged when Russian troops do stuff like this, and rightly so. We should be similarly outraged when friendly forces do such things. This wasn’t a small bunch of soldiers going rogue, this was an institutionalised disregard for the ethics of warfare and established military protocol.

This is horrifying. All these people should be brought to justice. No whitewashing for european armies if they behave like bloodthirsty monster on the field. 

An army that behaves like a mad beast should be restrained and reformed and the leaders that allowed it should be imprisoned and be made to paid for their complicity if not outright orders to do this. For all the supposed "responsibilities" of command that justifiers their higher salaries and benefits, they don't seem to accept the consequences of their failed leadership when the chickens come home to roost.
Heads up bbc keeps changing the headline so don’t delete or report if it happens third time.

It was a blatant and abhorrent invasion from day one:

1. The sorry excuse of WMD to invade a foreign country by a set of countries playing games for their own personal gains.
2. Studies say that around 0.5 Million people died due to the invasion and many more injured.
3. Not to mention the damage to the infrastructure, political structures and the economic impact on the country invaded.

The media is complicit in all of this as the coverage was shameful to say the least. They have parroted the official propagandized versions for so long. The UN, for what its worth did not authorize the invasion.

Did any of the true decision makers face the law due to this? Is there any guilt shown at the very least? Did some of them line-up their own pockets throughout this ordeal?

This will answer why massive "mistakes" of this ilk are being repeated at an alarming frequency.

Sources:

[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-24547256](https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-24547256)

[https://watson.brown.edu/costsofwar/costs/human/civilians](https://watson.brown.edu/costsofwar/costs/human/civilians)
As humans our capacity for inhumane violence is impressive and 100% depressing.

At this point, we should all understand that these kinds of things will be happening any time we're sending people into these sorts of situations. War makes monsters of people, or at least lets monsters thrive. Is whatever we're doing with those boots on the ground worth that price?

Over the past 3 years the factions and people that I thought were at least okay have turned out to be the real terrorists. Imagine spending all your life believing that you were on the right side of history and realising that you were oh so wrong.
They’ve been at it for centuries. Thank you to the brave people telling the truth.

If planting pistols by the bodies became routine does that mean taking bags of spare pistols on mission became routine?

I am just saying, pistols don't appear from thin air, to plant them you must have them first.

So we live in a world where bushels of spare guns were taken, or a world where someone lies or exegarates about what happened for (media) attention.

Not sure on the odds for either.

posts.title: Equipment issue again disrupts air traffic at Newark Liberty airport: FAA
top_comments: So Newark has been blinded 4 times, the Harry S Truman has lost 3 multimillion dollar jets, and there have been multiple near misses near Reagan. Not a great week for aviation.
Do they just not have it support there anymore?

*The incident marks the fourth time in the past two weeks that technical problems have disrupted air traffic at Newark Liberty*.

Well, if any worker speaks out, he or she may get a few lines of coverage and then vanish both from a job and further coverage.

Article by Bill Hutchinson, Sam Sweeney, and Ayesha Ali 

>Air traffic control [problems](https://www.goodmorningamerica.com/News/video/major-flight-disruptions-newark-airport-air-traffic-controllers-121463611) continued at Newark Liberty International Airport on Sunday morning after an equipment issue prompted the Federal Aviation Administration to order a 45-minute ground stop at the New Jersey airport, officials said.

>The FAA said in a statement that a telecommunications issue at the Philadelphia TRACON (terminal radar approach control) Area C facility, which guides aircraft in and out of Newark, caused the agency to issue a ground stop.

>"The FAA briefly slowed aircraft in and out of the airport while we ensured redundancies were working as designed," the FAA said in its [statement](https://x.com/FAANews/status/1921578482863104259).

>As of 11 a.m. ET, the FAA said, "operations have returned to normal" at Newark Liberty.

>On Sunday afternoon, the FAA released updated information, saying an audio issue, not an outage, prompted the ground stop at Newark. The agency said there were popping sounds on an unspecified number of radio frequencies. While air traffic controllers were able to communicate with aircraft, the radio system was not working correctly, prompting the switch to a backup system, the FAA said.

>The incident marks the fourth time in the past two weeks that technical problems have disrupted air traffic at Newark Liberty.

>On Friday morning, [radar screens at the airport went black](https://abcnews.go.com/US/radar-screens-newark-airport-black-overnight/story?id=121638395) for approximately 90 seconds, according to the FAA. During the outage, which occurred at about 3:55 a.m. ET, air traffic controllers could be heard telling a FedEx plane that their screens had gone dark and then asking the aircraft to tell their company to apply pressure to get the problem fixed.

>In another transmission, a controller told an arriving private jet that the airport just had experienced a brief radar outage and to stay at or above 3,000 feet in case the controllers couldn't get in touch during the aircraft's descent.

>The FAA said that the Friday outage stemmed from a "telecommunications outage that impacted communications and radar display at Philadelphia TRACON Area C," which is the facility that covers the airspace around Newark.

>On April 28, an [outage at Newark Liberty](https://abcnews.go.com/US/newark-airport-outage-week-lasted-60-90-seconds/story?id=121484044) caused air traffic control computer screens to go dark for roughly 60 to 90 seconds and also prevented the controllers from talking to aircraft during the outage, multiple sources with knowledge of the incident told ABC News. As a result, the FAA halted all departures to the Newark airport, citing "telecommunications and equipment issues at Philadelphia TRACON."

>ABC News also confirmed a minor outage at Newark Liberty that occurred on April 30.

>Following the April 29 outage, several controllers went on medical leave, calling the experience a traumatic event. The controllers are entitled to at least 45 days away from the job and must be evaluated by a doctor before they can return to work.
Where are the whistleblowers to tell us about how all the jobs that were cut are one of the reasons for this?

The Republicans talk out both sides of their ass, they canceled all of Biden’s plans in place to improve infrastructure so they could put the cash into their pockets and then they start blaming everybody else for the situation.
Is there actually anything wrong with the equipment, or is this just being done to justify Trump's "upgrade" and privatization of the air traffic control system?
Anyone think about moving the extension cord so people stop tripping over it?
Years of neglect has taken its toll and now the chickens have come to roost.
Don’t worry, it’s Phil Murphy’s fault according to the blowhards in my Newark suburb neighborhood facebook group

posts.title: The FDA approves first U.S. at-home tool as a Pap-smear alternative
top_comments: This tiny spot of good news is like when it rains *very lightly* for like 6 seconds, during a raging hellfire inferno that's destroying everything around you.

Sweet fuck thank you. I had an iud put in that went terribly wrong, leading to the Dr having to caulderize my cervix. Since then, even pap smears are too much for me. I put them off as long as I can due to anxiety, clenching, and pain. I'll definitely be using this as soon as it's available.

*Article Text by Jennifer Ludden:* 

The Food and Drug administration has approved the U.S.'s first at-home alternative to the Pap smear, a procedure generations of women have dreaded and often found painful.

The new device by Teal Health will offer a "much preferred experience," the company said in its announcement, and also aims to increase screening rates by making the procedure more convenient.

Traditionally, gynecologists have inserted a cold metal speculum deep into a woman's vagina to scrape cells from the cervix.

The Teal Wand — "built with empathy," the company said — uses a swab to collect a vaginal sample. Women will then mail the sample to a lab that will screen for HPV (human papillomavirus), the virus that causes nearly all cervical cancers. A growing body of research has found HPV testing to be highly accurate.

The FDA approval Friday follows a U.S.-based study that found at-home screening was just as effective as that done in a doctor's office. The study also found women overwhelmingly preferred self–screening at home, and said they'd be more likely to stay up to date with cervical cancer screenings that way.

Every year, about 13,000 cases of cervical cancer are diagnosed, and more than 4,000 women die from the disease. Rates are down dramatically since Dr. Georgios Papanicolaou published a 1943 paper on how to use the Pap smear for screening, and it then became common.

But about a quarter of women in the U.S. are behind on such screenings, and medical experts say reducing that is key to the ultimate goal of eliminating cervical cancer. There's also a racial gap, with Black and Native American women far more likely to die from cervical cancer than white women. The HPV vaccine for teen and preteen girls, introduced in 2007, has also led to a global push to tackle the disease that way.

At-home cervical cancer screenings are already available in several other countries, including Australia and Sweden.

Teal Health says its self-testing device will be available starting next month, in California first and then expanding. It will be by prescription, through a telehealth service, for women 25-65 years old who are "at average risk." The company says it's working with insurance companies to provide coverage.
Canada’s had this for a while. Much better alternative.

Is much rather do it myself because I can slow down or stop when I feel pain or discomfort. Someone else just rams it in there and the whole process doesn’t go fast enough so the discomfort and pain last longer. 

Also, I had an inexperienced doctor react like she was revolted because she mistook what is a backed up sebaceous gland for an HPV wart. She literally jumped back from me and treated me like I was diseased. The HPV test was negative. I never went back to her and the last I heard she moved to the urgent care clinic where she belongs.
So is it for vaginal samples or cervical, or both? The article flip-flops and it's not clear which it is.
Women's healthcare choices often feel like cutting off your hand or cutting off your finger.
Finally!

This is great. I have had two paps in my life and I'm 35. I got them both out of necessity for birth control and have since been sterilized. I'd prefer to do this at home in private than have someone else staring into the abyss, ya know. I'm very (to a fault) protective over my dignity.
I've been avoiding my pap smear like the plague because of the gender dysphoria. Looking forward to this being available in AZ

posts.title: 4 dead, hundreds displaced by Milwaukee apartment building fire
top_comments: That is terrible.  I feel so bad for everyone there.

Such a tragedy, and on Mother’s Day is so heartbreaking. It’s horrifying to find out just how preventable these deaths were. 

There are so many apartment buildings here in Milwaukee built before 1974 that may also not be required to have sprinkler systems. I hope something is done to address this loophole. 

Reminds me of [another incident](https://www.fox6now.com/news/uwm-carbon-monoxide-code-loophole) in Milwaukee a few years ago where several students in a UW Milwaukee dorm almost died from carbon monoxide poisoning, the dorm building was not required to have co2 alarms due to a loophole.

“Regulations are written in blood”

Words to live by

Edit:

> Both affiliates quoted crews as saying the building did not have a working sprinkler system but did not require one, as it was built before 1974, WTMJ reported.


Why is this building still stand? Which carve-out allow this?
If a building is too expensive to retrofit to make safe than it should not rented out to people.

posts.title: Trump fires director of U.S. Copyright Office, sources say
top_comments:
"...Perlmutter's firing was "a brazen, unprecedented power grab with no legal basis.... surely no coincidence he acted less than a day after she refused to rubber-stamp Elon Musk's efforts to mine troves of copyrighted works to train AI models," in reference to the report released by the Copyright Office this week.  

Last month, Musk took to his social media platform X to seemingly express support for the abolition of intellectual property laws..."

He sure is firing people left and right. Is there a website that tracks all the government heads that are being fired? I know I posted earlier that he fired the Librarian for Congress Friday. [https://federalnewsnetwork.com/workforce/2025/05/president-donald-trump-fires-librarian-of-congress-carla-hayden/](https://federalnewsnetwork.com/workforce/2025/05/president-donald-trump-fires-librarian-of-congress-carla-hayden/)

Edit: Added another name and more details who has been fired..Earlier Thursday, the [acting administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency](https://apnews.com/article/fema-trump-administrator-replaced-emergency-b9ae5e6a7e1c09e51de99c5148f45eb2) was pushed out one day after he had testified that he did not agree with proposals to dismantle the organization. Trump has suggested that individual states, not FEMA, should take the lead on responding to hurricanes, tornadoes and other crises.

At the Pentagon, more than a half-dozen [top general officers have been fired](https://apnews.com/article/trump-brown-joint-chiefs-of-staff-firing-fa428cc1508a583b3bf5e7a5a58f6acf) since January, including the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. CQ Brown Jr. The only two women serving as four-star officers, as well as a disproportionate number of other senior female officers, have also been fired.
We all know the intellectual property laws are only going to be suspended for the rich and corporations
We're cooked.  Elon can just steal whatever he wants now
Trump, gutting US civilization.
Damn I was half joking when I said this office was going to be fired for denying Elons copyright claims and it happens less than a week later. This is going into banana republic levels of corruption.
Strikes me as an admission that Elon's underlings weren't skilled enough to steal copyrighted work like every other major AI company does.
Wasn’t this the issue that started the first Trade War with China?
Musk had to stop the director’s report that his xAI training is copyright infringement.

There's going to be a lot of iconic American IP from massive corporations that are going to be against this. In fact copyright claims mainly benefit large corporations that can pursue the claims legally.

posts.title: 4 dead, hundreds displaced by Milwaukee apartment building fire
top_comments: That is terrible.  I feel so bad for everyone there.

Such a tragedy, and on Mother’s Day is so heartbreaking. It’s horrifying to find out just how preventable these deaths were. 

There are so many apartment buildings here in Milwaukee built before 1974 that may also not be required to have sprinkler systems. I hope something is done to address this loophole. 

Reminds me of [another incident](https://www.fox6now.com/news/uwm-carbon-monoxide-code-loophole) in Milwaukee a few years ago where several students in a UW Milwaukee dorm almost died from carbon monoxide poisoning, the dorm building was not required to have co2 alarms due to a loophole.

“Regulations are written in blood”

Words to live by

Edit:

> Both affiliates quoted crews as saying the building did not have a working sprinkler system but did not require one, as it was built before 1974, WTMJ reported.


Why is this building still stand? Which carve-out allow this?
If a building is too expensive to retrofit to make safe than it should not rented out to people.

top_comments:
This happened in my hometown 20 years ago or so. We lived well over a mile away, I thought someone had rammed their car into our house.  
A coworker lived across the street and down a couple from the house that exploded, he was walking up his basement stairs at the time, the blast knocked him back down the stairs.

“The explosion occurred at 2pm” then two paragraphs later, “the blast happened at 2:02am”

Nice job, news
I got 50/50 it was either a gas leak or a meth lab.

> A massive explosion that leveled a New Jersey home early Sunday and reportedly killed two people was so powerful that neighbors said it sounded like a bomb going off.


The explosion sounded like a bomb? You don’t say.
So for those of you also absolutely terrified what are things a home owner can do to assure that their gas line is not a ticking time bomb
This sounds scary similar to that explosion in Texas that was caused by a leaking natural gas line.
"Tranquility Court" doesn't live up to its name
Every time this happens I'm happy my home doesn't have a gas line.
I've seen this episode of Aqua Teen Hunger Force
That's sad. Two people died.  they were probably talking about what to do for dinner that night or maybe going to Target soon.

posts.title: Equipment issue again disrupts air traffic at Newark Liberty airport: FAA
top_comments: So Newark has been blinded 4 times, the Harry S Truman has lost 3 multimillion dollar jets, and there have been multiple near misses near Reagan. Not a great week for aviation.
Do they just not have it support there anymore?

*The incident marks the fourth time in the past two weeks that technical problems have disrupted air traffic at Newark Liberty*.

Well, if any worker speaks out, he or she may get a few lines of coverage and then vanish both from a job and further coverage.

Article by Bill Hutchinson, Sam Sweeney, and Ayesha Ali 

>Air traffic control [problems](https://www.goodmorningamerica.com/News/video/major-flight-disruptions-newark-airport-air-traffic-controllers-121463611) continued at Newark Liberty International Airport on Sunday morning after an equipment issue prompted the Federal Aviation Administration to order a 45-minute ground stop at the New Jersey airport, officials said.

>The FAA said in a statement that a telecommunications issue at the Philadelphia TRACON (terminal radar approach control) Area C facility, which guides aircraft in and out of Newark, caused the agency to issue a ground stop.

>"The FAA briefly slowed aircraft in and out of the airport while we ensured redundancies were working as designed," the FAA said in its [statement](https://x.com/FAANews/status/1921578482863104259).

>As of 11 a.m. ET, the FAA said, "operations have returned to normal" at Newark Liberty.

>On Sunday afternoon, the FAA released updated information, saying an audio issue, not an outage, prompted the ground stop at Newark. The agency said there were popping sounds on an unspecified number of radio frequencies. While air traffic controllers were able to communicate with aircraft, the radio system was not working correctly, prompting the switch to a backup system, the FAA said.

>The incident marks the fourth time in the past two weeks that technical problems have disrupted air traffic at Newark Liberty.

>On Friday morning, [radar screens at the airport went black](https://abcnews.go.com/US/radar-screens-newark-airport-black-overnight/story?id=121638395) for approximately 90 seconds, according to the FAA. During the outage, which occurred at about 3:55 a.m. ET, air traffic controllers could be heard telling a FedEx plane that their screens had gone dark and then asking the aircraft to tell their company to apply pressure to get the problem fixed.

>In another transmission, a controller told an arriving private jet that the airport just had experienced a brief radar outage and to stay at or above 3,000 feet in case the controllers couldn't get in touch during the aircraft's descent.

>The FAA said that the Friday outage stemmed from a "telecommunications outage that impacted communications and radar display at Philadelphia TRACON Area C," which is the facility that covers the airspace around Newark.

>On April 28, an [outage at Newark Liberty](https://abcnews.go.com/US/newark-airport-outage-week-lasted-60-90-seconds/story?id=121484044) caused air traffic control computer screens to go dark for roughly 60 to 90 seconds and also prevented the controllers from talking to aircraft during the outage, multiple sources with knowledge of the incident told ABC News. As a result, the FAA halted all departures to the Newark airport, citing "telecommunications and equipment issues at Philadelphia TRACON."

>ABC News also confirmed a minor outage at Newark Liberty that occurred on April 30.

>Following the April 29 outage, several controllers went on medical leave, calling the experience a traumatic event. The controllers are entitled to at least 45 days away from the job and must be evaluated by a doctor before they can return to work.
Where are the whistleblowers to tell us about how all the jobs that were cut are one of the reasons for this?

The Republicans talk out both sides of their ass, they canceled all of Biden’s plans in place to improve infrastructure so they could put the cash into their pockets and then they start blaming everybody else for the situation.
Is there actually anything wrong with the equipment, or is this just being done to justify Trump's "upgrade" and privatization of the air traffic control system?
Anyone think about moving the extension cord so people stop tripping over it?
Years of neglect has taken its toll and now the chickens have come to roost.
Don’t worry, it’s Phil Murphy’s fault according to the blowhards in my Newark suburb neighborhood facebook group

posts.title: 'Children handcuffed and shot' - ex-UK Special Forces break silence on war crime claims
top_comments:
"Former members of UK Special Forces have broken years of silence to give BBC Panorama eyewitness accounts of alleged war crimes committed by colleagues in Iraq and Afghanistan.

Giving their accounts publicly for the first time, the veterans described seeing members of the SAS murder unarmed people in their sleep and execute handcuffed detainees, including children.

"They handcuffed a young boy and shot him," recalled one veteran who served with the SAS in Afghanistan. "He was clearly a child, not even close to fighting age."

Killing of detainees "became routine", the veteran said. "They'd search someone, handcuff them, then shoot them", before cutting off the plastic handcuffs used to restrain people and "planting a pistol" by the body, he said.

...

Knowledge of the alleged crimes was not confined to small teams or individual squadrons, according to the testimony. Within the UK Special Forces command structure, "everyone knew" what was happening, said one veteran.

...

"There was a fake grenade they'd take with them onto target, it couldn't detonate," said a former SAS operator. Another veteran said operators would carry AK-47 rifles which had a folding stock because they were easier to fit into their rucksacks and "easier to bring onto a target and plant by a body".

Officers would then help to falsify post-operational reports in order to avoid scrutiny for the actions of assault teams on the ground, according to the testimony.

...

"If it looked like a shooting could represent a breach of the rules of conflict, you'd get a phone call from the legal adviser or one of the staff officers in HQ. They'd pick you up on it and help you to clarify the language. 'Do you remember someone making a sudden move?' 'Oh yeah, I do now.' That sort of thing. It was built into the way we operated."

The reports were "a fiction", another UKSF veteran said.

An intelligence officer who worked with the SBS described reports which said they had been caught in a firefight, while the photos showed bodies with "multiple clean headshots".

...

The Afghan president was "so consistent with his complaints about night raids, civilian casualties and detentions that there was no senior Western diplomat or military leader who would have missed the fact that this was a major irritant for him," said Gen Douglas Lute, a former US ambassador to Nato.

..."

We are outraged when Russian troops do stuff like this, and rightly so. We should be similarly outraged when friendly forces do such things. This wasn’t a small bunch of soldiers going rogue, this was an institutionalised disregard for the ethics of warfare and established military protocol.

This is horrifying. All these people should be brought to justice. No whitewashing for european armies if they behave like bloodthirsty monster on the field. 

An army that behaves like a mad beast should be restrained and reformed and the leaders that allowed it should be imprisoned and be made to paid for their complicity if not outright orders to do this. For all the supposed "responsibilities" of command that justifiers their higher salaries and benefits, they don't seem to accept the consequences of their failed leadership when the chickens come home to roost.
Heads up bbc keeps changing the headline so don’t delete or report if it happens third time.

It was a blatant and abhorrent invasion from day one:

1. The sorry excuse of WMD to invade a foreign country by a set of countries playing games for their own personal gains.
2. Studies say that around 0.5 Million people died due to the invasion and many more injured.
3. Not to mention the damage to the infrastructure, political structures and the economic impact on the country invaded.

The media is complicit in all of this as the coverage was shameful to say the least. They have parroted the official propagandized versions for so long. The UN, for what its worth did not authorize the invasion.

Did any of the true decision makers face the law due to this? Is there any guilt shown at the very least? Did some of them line-up their own pockets throughout this ordeal?

This will answer why massive "mistakes" of this ilk are being repeated at an alarming frequency.

Sources:

[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-24547256](https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-24547256)

[https://watson.brown.edu/costsofwar/costs/human/civilians](https://watson.brown.edu/costsofwar/costs/human/civilians)
As humans our capacity for inhumane violence is impressive and 100% depressing.

At this point, we should all understand that these kinds of things will be happening any time we're sending people into these sorts of situations. War makes monsters of people, or at least lets monsters thrive. Is whatever we're doing with those boots on the ground worth that price?

Over the past 3 years the factions and people that I thought were at least okay have turned out to be the real terrorists. Imagine spending all your life believing that you were on the right side of history and realising that you were oh so wrong.
They’ve been at it for centuries. Thank you to the brave people telling the truth.

If planting pistols by the bodies became routine does that mean taking bags of spare pistols on mission became routine?

I am just saying, pistols don't appear from thin air, to plant them you must have them first.

So we live in a world where bushels of spare guns were taken, or a world where someone lies or exegarates about what happened for (media) attention.

Not sure on the odds for either.

posts.title: The FDA approves first U.S. at-home tool as a Pap-smear alternative
top_comments: This tiny spot of good news is like when it rains *very lightly* for like 6 seconds, during a raging hellfire inferno that's destroying everything around you.

Sweet fuck thank you. I had an iud put in that went terribly wrong, leading to the Dr having to caulderize my cervix. Since then, even pap smears are too much for me. I put them off as long as I can due to anxiety, clenching, and pain. I'll definitely be using this as soon as it's available.

*Article Text by Jennifer Ludden:* 

The Food and Drug administration has approved the U.S.'s first at-home alternative to the Pap smear, a procedure generations of women have dreaded and often found painful.

The new device by Teal Health will offer a "much preferred experience," the company said in its announcement, and also aims to increase screening rates by making the procedure more convenient.

Traditionally, gynecologists have inserted a cold metal speculum deep into a woman's vagina to scrape cells from the cervix.

The Teal Wand — "built with empathy," the company said — uses a swab to collect a vaginal sample. Women will then mail the sample to a lab that will screen for HPV (human papillomavirus), the virus that causes nearly all cervical cancers. A growing body of research has found HPV testing to be highly accurate.

The FDA approval Friday follows a U.S.-based study that found at-home screening was just as effective as that done in a doctor's office. The study also found women overwhelmingly preferred self–screening at home, and said they'd be more likely to stay up to date with cervical cancer screenings that way.

Every year, about 13,000 cases of cervical cancer are diagnosed, and more than 4,000 women die from the disease. Rates are down dramatically since Dr. Georgios Papanicolaou published a 1943 paper on how to use the Pap smear for screening, and it then became common.

But about a quarter of women in the U.S. are behind on such screenings, and medical experts say reducing that is key to the ultimate goal of eliminating cervical cancer. There's also a racial gap, with Black and Native American women far more likely to die from cervical cancer than white women. The HPV vaccine for teen and preteen girls, introduced in 2007, has also led to a global push to tackle the disease that way.

At-home cervical cancer screenings are already available in several other countries, including Australia and Sweden.

Teal Health says its self-testing device will be available starting next month, in California first and then expanding. It will be by prescription, through a telehealth service, for women 25-65 years old who are "at average risk." The company says it's working with insurance companies to provide coverage.
Canada’s had this for a while. Much better alternative.

Is much rather do it myself because I can slow down or stop when I feel pain or discomfort. Someone else just rams it in there and the whole process doesn’t go fast enough so the discomfort and pain last longer. 

Also, I had an inexperienced doctor react like she was revolted because she mistook what is a backed up sebaceous gland for an HPV wart. She literally jumped back from me and treated me like I was diseased. The HPV test was negative. I never went back to her and the last I heard she moved to the urgent care clinic where she belongs.
So is it for vaginal samples or cervical, or both? The article flip-flops and it's not clear which it is.
Women's healthcare choices often feel like cutting off your hand or cutting off your finger.
Finally!

This is great. I have had two paps in my life and I'm 35. I got them both out of necessity for birth control and have since been sterilized. I'd prefer to do this at home in private than have someone else staring into the abyss, ya know. I'm very (to a fault) protective over my dignity.
I've been avoiding my pap smear like the plague because of the gender dysphoria. Looking forward to this being available in AZ

MAGA Official:  'We're going to take Gaza completely, and build resort casinos on every inch of the land - and, in exchange, you and all the Palestinians can go elsewhere!'

Hamas:  'Death to Israel and the Great Satan!!!  Wait, what???  Elsewhere???  Where exactly is elsewhere?'

MAGA Official:  'Doesn't matter!  Anywhere else is fine...  Well, you're going to want to avoid Israel - and don't even think of coming to the USA!'

Hamas:  'And what exactly do we get for giving you absolutely everything?'

MAGA Official:  'I already told you!  You get to go elsewhere!  We get Gaza, and you get to F right off!'

Hamas:  [Throws up hands and shrugs.]

MAGA Official:  'And, next time, instead of traditional formal-robes, you should probably put on suits and say 'Thank You!'
